awd_titl_txt: Coordinating Curricula and User Preferences to Increase the Participation of Women and Students of Color in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
For several decades, academic institutions have received financial resources to broaden participation in engineering programs.  Despite these funded recruitment and retention efforts, most engineering programs have achieved little improvement in the participation of women, students of color, individuals with disabilities, and other underrepresented groups. One hypothesis to explain this discrepancy is that the low representation of women and students of color in engineering results from the lack of accessibility of engineering curricula.  To test this hypothesis, this project seeks to study engineering curricula and student preferences.  Based on those results, it aims to develop a set of curriculum guidelines and models that may increase the alignment between engineering curricula and students' expectations and preferences for learning.   These results have the potential to broaden participation of women and students of color in engineering.
 
The project uses an exploratory sequential mixed methods design, which begins with exploratory activities and builds to more systematic testing of research questions concerning how particular user preferences influence student participation. Investigators will engage in data mining of syllabi, course content, public spaces, and instructor materials to aggregate information about curricula presented in different representational forms, such as equations, images, narratives, simulations, and videos. From these data, it is anticipated that qualitatively and quantitatively distinct profiles of course representations will be generated.  The investigators will track longitudinal persistence of students in STEM, in relationship to course structure and individual learner preferences.  Understanding the intersection between learner preferences and engineering curricula has the potential to improve engineering education and broaden participation in the field of engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For several decades, academic institutions have received financial resources to broaden participation in undergraduate engineering programs in higher education. Despite these funded recruitment and retention efforts, most engineering programs have achieved little improvement in the matriculation and participation of women, students of color, individuals with disabilities, and other underrepresented groups. The project, Coordinating Curricula and User Preferences to Increase the Participation of Women and Students of Color in Engineering (CUE4CHNG), investigated whether the discrepancy of low representation of women and students of color in engineering partially results from the lack of accessibility of diverse engineering curricula.  In other words, is there diversity in the presentation of engineering curricula ( e.g., text, equations, two and three representations, interactive simulations) in undergraduate classroom environments.

The goal was to study engineering curricula and student preferences for developing a set of curriculum guidelines that may increase the alignment between engineering curricula and students' expectations and preferences for learning. 

Data was gathered for over 9,000 syllabi and classes were collected and educational keywords were identified on the syllabi to determine which content and constructs were used for teaching students in engineering courses.

The project organized focus groups and student online surveys to understand the preferences for presentation of classroom teaching and learning material. The survey presented five topics in engineering and math in a variety of ways, including text, equation, two and three dimensional illustrations with and without color, animations using the same variations as the illustrations, and an interactive simulation. Surveys of student learners informed the learning preferences of students in predominantly engineering classrooms in undergraduate education. Surveys of educators informed how instructors presented content to student learners and also preferences of content that would be delivered to students in a classroom environment.

Findings from this study resulted in learning something about student preferences regarding level of abstraction vs. verisimilitude in representations that might be transferable to a variety of students in other disciplinary areas. The base knowledge regarding student preferences may provide us with information that would improve student learning, and teacher-student improved interactions involving pedagogy. Additional research is needed to further investigate student preferences. This proof of concept research study provided the foundation to continue research on student learner preferences in undergraduate education. We found that there are differences in what students prefer in terms of learning and what teachers provide during instructional activities. 

Using diverse representations of theories and methods, experiences in learning may help improve students' learning experiences and ultimately improve student learning outcomes. For instance, at some universities, data communication lectures and labs on the 3G, 4G, and 5G networks can be delivered through computer simulations and/or actual manual signal measurements using different equipment modules (modulation, demodulation, beam forming, spread spectrum, etc.). These labs and lectures can be developed using different presentation formats taking into account students' preferences as discovered in this study. This also leads to our rethinking of the acquisition, maintenance, and upgrade of the lab equipment and tools to accommodate the diversified presentation and use needs.

Results of this study can have an impact on all the stages of information flow, from the information (content) generation, to information processing, to information management, and to information consumption. Academic information generates following the modes of observation, experimentation, processing of data, happening of various events, and so on. Regardless of the origin of the information, it must be presented and delivered in a way that the end user (student) may find it easy to appreciate, process it. Understanding the user’s experience and preference can thus help content generators and managers to achieve this goal. For instance, undergraduate student experiences in their first year of their engineering programs could include multiple representations of materials in different formats to meet the diversified needs and preferences of the students from diverse cultural, gender, and socioeconomic backgrounds to assist in advancing their academic studies.  

Course instructors teaching diverse student groups may also need to rethink how they present their materials. Presenting diverse representations of teaching and learning materials may make teaching more effective among diverse student populations.
